conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the geometry of the square and the arc, calculate necessary lengths, and determine the length of the arc where lights cannot directly exit.
The image shows a square ABCO with a point source of light at O. The arc AC is part of a circle with center O and radius R.
Since ABCO is a square, OA = OB = OC = R. The angle ∠AOB is 90°.
The arc AC is part of a circle with center O and radius R. The length of arc AC is given by the formula for the arc length: Arc Length = (θ/360) × 2πR.
Here, θ = 90°, so the length of arc AC is (90/360) × 2πR = πR/2.
The angle ∠AOB is 90°, so the angle ∠AOC is also 90°.
The angle ∠BOC is 90°, so the angle ∠BOC is also 90°.
The total angle around point O is 360°, so the remaining angle ∠COD is 360° - 90° - 90° = 180°.
The length of arc CD is given by the formula for the arc length: Arc Length = (θ/360) × 2πR.
Here, θ = 180°, so the length of arc CD is (180/360) × 2πR = πR.
The length of arc AC where lights cannot directly exit is the difference between the total arc length and the length of arc CD: πR/2 - πR = -πR/2.
